title: Identifying Your Core Domain - Knowledge Check

questions.question: What are the three types of subdomains in DDD?
questions.explanation: DDD identifies three types of subdomains: Core (provides competitive advantage), Supporting (necessary but not differentiating), and Generic (common functionality that can be bought off-the-shelf).

questions.question: What characterizes a Core Domain?

options.text: Simple business logic that rarely changes
Generic functionality that can be purchased from vendors
Unique to your business, complex logic, frequently changing, high business value
Infrastructure concerns like logging and monitoring

questions.explanation: Core Domain is unique to your business, has complex business logic, changes frequently, provides high business value, and cannot be bought off-the-shelf. It's your competitive advantage.

questions.question: You should apply full DDD rigor and assign your best developers to the Core Domain.
questions.explanation: The Core Domain is where you should invest the most. Apply full DDD rigor, assign your best developers, collaborate deeply with domain experts, use sophisticated patterns, and implement extensive testing.

questions.question: In an e-commerce platform, which would typically be a Core Domain?

options.text: Dynamic pricing engine with proprietary algorithms

questions.explanation: A dynamic pricing engine with proprietary algorithms is typically a Core Domain because it's unique to the business and provides competitive advantage. Authentication, email, and payment gateways are usually Generic or Supporting domains.

questions.question: Generic subdomains should be built in-house to maintain full control over the implementation.
questions.explanation: Generic subdomains are common functionality that doesn't differentiate your business. These should typically be purchased off-the-shelf or use open-source solutions. Build vs buy decisions should favor buying for Generic domains.
